Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This R&D study integrates American Sign Language (ASL) into the life and physical sciences content of 9th-12th grade deaf or hard-of-hearing students. TERC and Vcom3D incorporate the use of the Signing Avatar assistive technology in order to develop, research, and disseminate two illustrated interactive 3D dictionaries: Signing Life Science Dictionary (SLSD), and Signing Physical Science Dictionary (SPSD) with audio modes and approximately 750 standards-based terms in English and Spanish text that can be signed or listened to on demand. Two research questions guide the study: (1) What kinds of learning gains in life science are possible with the use of the SLSD?; and (2) What kinds of learning gains in physical science are possible with the use of the SPSD?

Proposers hypothesize that the use of both SLSD and SPSD will assist participants to increase their ability to sign, understand, and use the languages of life and physical sciences; improve their science content knowledge; and increase their ability to study each content area independently. The development phase of the study defines a nine-step plan for each dictionary: (1) developing English-based text components (signed terms, parts of speech, definitions, and examples); (2) integrating illustrations; (3) developing Spanish-based text components; (4) integrating narration; (5) refining the interface; (6) incorporating support materials; (7) testing; (8) evaluating project progress; and (9) disseminating results. The research phase employs a mixed-methods pretest-posttest, within-subjects research design. Each subject is tested in the experimental condition (with the dictionaries) and in the control condition (without the dictionaries). To determine the sample size, the G*Power software was used assuming a type I error of 0.05, a power of 0.80, and an effect size of 0.25 (based on previous work). A sample size of 100 was identified, but researchers increased it to 150 to address teacher attrition. Data gathering instruments include pretests and posttests focused on the appropriate use of the science vocabulary, content questionnaires, scoring criteria and rubrics, classroom observation and interview protocols, and post-use surveys. Quantitative data strategies include analysis of trends in pre-post learning within and between groups, such as change in vocabulary knowledge, content knowledge, and independence using procedures, such as paired t-test and ANOVA. Qualitative data analysis employs categorizing and synthesizing data, such as narrative analysis.

The final outcome of this study is a completed suite of research-informed and field-tested technology-enhanced tools to assist high school deaf and hard-of-hearing students to improve their life, physical, and earth sciences learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this R&D study, TERC and Vcom3D used the Signing Avatar assistive technology to develop, research, and disseminate two illustrated interactive 3D dictionaries for students who are deaf or hard-of hearing and use sign as their primary method of communication. One dictionary is a Signing Life Science Dictionary (SLSD); one is a Signing Physical Science Dictionary (SPSD). Each dictionary includes signing avatars and approximately 750 standards-based terms that are available in English and Spanish text and can be signed in American Sign Language (ASL) or Signed English (SE) and listened to on demand. The dictionaries incorporate the Universal Design for Learning (UDL) framework. This framework emphasizes three key aspects of pedagogy: 1) Information is represented in multiple ways. These include text, sign, audio, and pictures. 2) Users are offered opportunities for multiple means of expression of knowledge. These include speech and sign. 3) Users are offered opportunities for multiple means of engagement. These include selecting an avatar character, changing the signing speed, zooming and rotating the avatar, and selecting terms to sign. Integration of the framework offers the intended audience increased access to standards-based life science and physical science content through individualized use of the dictionaries.

     The Web-based versions of the dictionary are available free from the Signing Math & Science home page at https://signsci.terc.edu/index.html. The Web-based versions require a Windows OS, Internet Explorer, and a plug-in. The plug-in is available free and can be accessed from the Signing Math & Science home page. Video versions that are compatible with Mac, Chromebook, and a wide variety of platforms and web browsers and with iPads are available free from. https://signsci.terc.edu/video/ . App versions for use with iPhones are available from iTunes and can be accessed from http://www.signingapp.com/index_desktop.html .

     Findings from research conducted during field testing of the dictionaries indicate that the SLSD and SPSD, when used as assistive tools, contribute to giving students in grades 9-12 who are deaf or hard of hearing access to science vocabulary in their own language. They suggest students are likely better able to understand the grade-appropriate science content that they are studying. Results further indicate that teachers easily integrated the dictionaries into instruction and that their use enabled them to individualize instruction for a wide range of learners with varying levels of hearing loss and learning challenges. In addition, the Avatar technology seemed to motivate high school students and fire up their curiosity and interest in learning science vocabulary.

    The field-test research procedure that resulted in these findings incorporated a within-subjects mixed methods design. It involved placing the dictionaries in the designated classroom context, at the intended grade levels, with students who are deaf or hard of hearing. Purposeful sampling ensured that each class included students who: communicated using ASL; would be doing a unit that focused on standards-based life science or physical science content; could complete the unit within the testing timeframe; and had the requisite technology. This resulted in two cohorts of students using the Web-based dictionaries in different years. Results were organized into spreadsheets and analysis proceeded as follows. Pre/post-use (yes/no) data about students’ knowledge of the five terms identified were tallied. Pre-ability, post-ability, and pre-to-post change in ability were calculated as the percent total number of correct (yes) responses out of the total number possible. Information for ability to explain meanings and/or definitions was calculated as the average score for the group out of a maximum score of 3. Survey data for each class were organized according to perceived gains in learning, usability, use, and satisfaction. Coding rubrics were generated to code comments from students and from teachers within each of the categories. Responses to Yes/No or Likert scale items were tallied and sums calculated. Coded responses were analyzed to detect trends in the data that would provide insight from teachers and students.

     Ongoing research and development includes incorporating the terms into signing glossaries for use in museums by visitors who are deaf or hard of hearing and examining the degree to which they provide access to STEM exhibit content. The terms are also being incorporated into new technologies such as an app for members of the target population to use while reading Web pages that is intended to enable access to STEM Web page content.
